document.text: zation of all 4-H clubs. 4-H members should make sure they re-enroll in 4-H this fall to keep their membership cur rent. Check with us if youre not sure about membership status.    Several 4-Hers have asked about new community 4-H clubs in the Spout Spring and Vera areas of the county. All that is needed for a new community dub is a group of interested young people and several parents or other adults that will agree to help as adult leaders. It is difficult to have effective community 4-H dubs without adult leaders w ithin the community.    The Appomattox 4-H Teen Leader Club is planning on a special 4-H Talent Show for the Appomattox Railroad Festival. More details about tryouts will be available next week. All 4-H members will be eligible to partidpate.    Dont forget your 4-H projects, they will be due in mid October.

document.text: Wrack Island Extension Homemakers Club Matting Mrs. Marie Carson was hostess to the Wreck Island Ex tension Homemakers Club when it met in her home o n  Wednesday, September 20, at H30 p.m. There were 12 mem bers in attenance. One new member, Mrs. Zolene Harding was added to the roll. Mrs. Elsie Thornhill led devotions and prayer. She chose for the scripture reading Matt.7l-5. She gave a reading. The topic was Fog Dims The View . Hie secretary read the minutes and it was approved and the treasurer report was given. Mrs. Dixie Staten led the group in the Homemakers Creed. A business session wàs con ducted by our president, Mrs. Dixie Staten of announcements with dates of interest to mem bers. September 23-24 - Railroad Festival - The Appomattox County Homemakers are preparing a float for the Railroad Festival . The Float Committee decided that one person from each homemakers gçoup will be on the float to sing. Mrs. Frances Dyess will represent our club. September 28 Leader Training for October. Dr. Eldridge R. Collins, Exten sion Specialist with Ag Engineering will do the Leader Training Session for October. Sessions will be held at 130 p.m. and 730 p.m. on Safe Wood Burning in Stoves and Fireplaces. September 30, 1978 Achievement Day - to be held at the Appomattox County High School cafeteria for the Ap pomattox County Homemakers at 6 p.m. The theme for this program is Todays 4-Hers Tomorrows Homemakers. Three of our members, Mrs. Rose Burnett, Mrs. Mane Car- son and Mrs. Dixie Staten have signed up for needlepoint workshops that Dr. Helen Whidden of Lynchburg is con ducting September 7, 8, 14, 15, 19 and 21. It was announced that Mrs. Tilden Lee entered exhibits on canned goods, horticulture and flowers at the Five County Fair in Farmville, Sept. 11-16. She won 24 ribbons on her en tries. Thirteen blue ribbons were won which was the greatest number of blue ribbons won in the adult division to win the Grand Champion Award Trophy plus 10.00. Mrs. Lee entered seven exhibits at State Fair,- Rich mond, Va., and won seven rib bons, 4 of which were blue rib bons for her entries. Mrs. Ruth Carson, Federation Goal Chairman, gave a program topic, A Goal For Everyone. Breads of the World was the topic of the demonstration given by Mrs. Rose Burnett. A social hour followed when the hostess served delicious refreshments to the group. The October meeting will be held in the home of Mrs. Mary Taylor on Wed., Oct. 18, at 130 p.m. A demonstration on Safety to be given. The topic Safe Woodburning - Stoves and Fireplaces. document.text: with the job Ive bron doing, Britton added. When a public administrator feels that he may not be doing what his constituents want, then he has to consider moving on. I found that the people of Appomattox like the efforts I have made as town manager. Britton, a 1971 graduate of Virginia Commonwealth University with a B.S. degree in public administration, was hired as town manager in December of 1976.  Along with his regular duties as town manager, the Charlottesville native serves as treasurer for the town, town building official, town zoning and subdivision administrator, special projects assistant to theCounty Board of Supervisors, county fire marshall, and emergency and energy services coordinator for the county. He also serves on numerous boards and commissions for the town and county. He counts as one -of bis most enjoyed titles that of town clown for the annual Railroad Festival. - Britton said he is looking forward to working with the Appomattox com munity in many, many ways in the future....It sure is nice to be a part of the depot.

There will be approximately 70 units includ ing five bands, marching units, drill teams, floats, antique cars, equestrian entries, special guests and many other special attractions. document.text: Wins First Trophy For Best Marching Unit Dillard Guard Drill Team of Fork Union Military Academy, Fork Union won the trophy in the Railroad Festival Parade for the Best Marching Unit other than a band, the trophy donated by Moses Motor Company. The drill team was under the command of Cadet Lt. Carter W. Clark of South Hill and one of the highlights of the appearance was the solo rifle demonstration by Cadet Lt. Keith E. Kuck of Arlington and Cadet Staff Sgt. D. Brian Hanes of Roanoke. The Drill team says it was most impressed with our town and especially with the hospitaity shown them as a group. They enjoyed the day very much.

document.text: Winnie-The-Pooh To Visit Historic Railroad Festival A big attraction for the children at our third annual Historic Railroad Festival will be the popular Winnie-the- Pooh bear, a registered trademark and copyright of Walt Disney Productions. There are seven Winnie-the- Poohs that are owned by Sears, Roebuck and Company, Inc. and Walt Disney Produc tion to be loaned throughout the nation exclusively for the entertainment of children in the Sears department stores and various festivities. Winnie-the- Pooh was secured by the Appomattox Junior Womans Club in co-operation with Sears Roebuck and Co. of Lynchburg. Winnie-the-Pooh is allowed only one annual visit to the Sears Lynchburg Store which was in July of this year. While in Lynchburg, he visited the childrens ward in the two local hospitals, Lynchburg training School and hospital, various nurseries, and the children s department in the Lynchburg Sears Store. For this reason, we should be proud to have Winnie-the-Pooh back so soon to this area to join in our Historic Railroad Festival. He will make his first appearance in our parade at 10 a.m. Saturday thereafter, during the festival he will be on Main Street to entertain the young people. So, Mom and Dad bnng the whole family out for two days of historical education, musical entertainment, fun and recreat ion for the children, and much, much more. OFFICE SUPPLIES YouI find a lot of those hard to find items among our selection of Office Supplies on display in our office. Come in and take a look! Times-Virginian. In the kindergarten through grade 2 category, first-place winner was Thomas Nolen, second-place winner was Hea ther Martin, third-place winner was Nicole Randolph, and the work of Daphne Jackson and LaTasha Johnson, received honorable mention. In the grade 3 through 5 category, first place went to Mike Whitmer, second place went to Sarah Mitchell, third place to Rodney Thompson, and Angie Thompson and Joe Servis received honorable mention. In the grades 6 through 8 Category, first place went to Cheryl Wooten, second place went to Angie Whitmer, third place went to John Ackerman, and honorable mention went to Paul Sheen and Debbie Hail. In the grades 9 through 12 category first place went to Bruce McClary, second dace went to Teresa Mayberry, third place went to Ron Carter, and honorable mention, went to Rosa , Harvey and- Randy Phelps. , Judges for the event were Jennifer Midgett, Wendy Ric hardson, Emily Burke, and Susan Weatherly. document.text: UDC DINNER MEETING The Appomattox Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy met on Thurs., May 20 at6 p.m. at the home of Mrs. Helen Gunter. There were 17 members and one visitor in attendance. Pledges to the United States Flag and salutes of the Virginia Flag and the Confederate Flag were led by the president, Mrs. Lena Eversole. The ritual was read by Mrs. Mary Moore and the Confederate prayer by Mrs. Geneva Childers. An invitation has been extended to members to attend the Massing of the Flags in Richmond on Thurs., June 3. Members are planning to enter a float in the 4th Railroad Festival to be held Oct. 15 and 16. Mrs. Eversole appointed the following committee for this - Mrs. Noma Rae Moore, chairman and Mrs. Harriett Cunningham, Mrs. Lena Ever sole, Mrs. Mary Moore, Mrs. M argaret Lee, Mrs. Ruby Lewis, Mrs. Louise Plunkett and Mrs. Frances Harvey. Cards are being sent to our shut-ins. Mrs. Lucille Ferrell, histor ian, gave an interesting talk on William Ranson Pegram, a colonel during the Civil War, who is described by one of his officers as The Truest Christian, the most faithful and the most superb soldier in all the world. Mrs. Marion Tweedy return ed thanks for our evening meal. A memorial service was then

document.text: The year 1975 marks an important milestone in our communitys history. It will be fifty years from the incorpora tion of the Town of Appomat tox, as well as the Bicentennial Year of many historic events in the founding of our nation. For the past two years, the Historic Appomattox Railroad Festival has demonstrated the kinds of immediate and long run benefits of total community involvement in a historic celebration. For example, the festivals resulted in the final deeding of the NW Railroad Depot to the Town, the start of a community Arts  Crafts Center in the station, the pride of Appomattoxs unique Civil War-Railroad history, the em placement of a historic land mark plaque in downtowr Appomattox, and a nationa, reputation for a memorable annual event.

document.text: The stage is set for the Ninth Annual Historic Appomattox County Railroad Festival, scheduled to get underway this Saturday at 10 a.m. The festival, initiated, in 1972, is regarded as the single biggest event of the year for Appomatox and has in past years attracted between 5,000 and 6,000 visitors during the festivals two days. This years version of the festival begins at 10 a.m. with the festival parade, featuring grand marshalls, the Hon. Watkins Abbitt, former U. S. Congressman Dr. Clyde G. -OBrien, noted local physician and the Rev. R. Q. Lawing, noted local clergyman. The parade will originate at the Appomattox Primary School and proceed through Appomattox to the Depot oh Main Street, then double back and terminate at the Primary School. Greetings and introductions will be made at the Train Depot at 11 a.m., after which the days festivities will commence. Throughout the day Satur day and Sunday will be arts and crafts displays, food for sale by local church and civic organiza tions, railroad and other historic exhibits, country, blue- grass, gospel and railroad music, and a variety of games and amusements. Specific events planned for Saturday, aside from the parade and opening cere monies, include the . Joe Sweeney 10K run starting at the county high school at 1 p.m.4-H Share-The Fun state competition from 1230 to 1 pjp. a, country and western square-aancing exniDiuon downtown from 1 p.m. to 145, and a ground and areial fireworks display starting at 8 p.m. at Appomattox County High School. Sundays special events include a rugby football game at Bragg Stadium off Route 460 starting at 2 p.m. and a karate demonstration on Har rell Street starting at 130 p.m. - Open House will he held at the town fire hall from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m. on Saturday and Sunday. Stuffed toys, ceramics, jewelry, apple doUs, thumbprint art, character photos, T-shirts, horse collar m irrors, and numerous hand crafts, includ ing bonnets, aprons, afghans, pillows, flower arrangements,, doUs, clothing, etc. There wiU also be an art exhibit, with paints for seU. Demonstrations can be viewed on apple doU making, sketch portraits, thumbprint art on the spot, card weaving, and making walking canes. This years art and crafts exhibits promise to be an exciting event of the Festival, an event featuring something for every member of the family. You will not want to miss seeing every exhibit. document.text: The last action is an effort to cut down the towns expenses when they must turn off the main water supply to houses which are undergoing plumbing repairs or maintenance. In other action council voted to co-sponsor, with the Appo mattox Junior Womans Club, the 1975 Historic Appomattox Railroad Festival in 1975. The festival is tentatively scheduled for the first week end in October. Council denied a request tendered by David Nash which would allow a development of Nashs sewage access, and in a separate but related action, heard a request from James A. Nolen concerning the relocating of the towns east sewage lagoon. Action on a motion by councilman Ronald C. Spiggle, council voted to contact the chairman of the State Water Control Board in an effort to raise the Appomattox priority for federal and state funding for construction of a new sewage treatment plant. Council also approved a -change of parking limits on N. Church Street, between High land Avenue and Confederate Blvd. The limit was raised from one hour to three hours. Mayor Henry Pack informed council that the town would pay a fosil fuel surcharge to Virginia Electric Power Com pany. The surcharge will mean almost 100 per cent increase in the towns electric bill. Council also voted to give 1,120 feet of Dogwood Avenue and 302 feet of West Street to the State Highway Department so that the streets may be paved. When resurfacing is completed, Dogwood Avenue will be complete from Ever green Avenue to Lee-Grant Avenue.

document.text: The fourth annual Historic Appomattox Railroad Festival will be held this year on Oct. 16 and 17. Hours will be. 10 a.m. until 5 p.m. on Saturday and 1 until 5 p.m. on Sunday. A kick-off parade will begin on Saturday at 10 a.m. This years grand marshal will be county musk Grand Ole Opry Star, Ray Pillow of Nashville. Pillow, along with Doyle Holly, and the Vanishing Breed of Nashville, will perform for two shows Satur day night at the Appomattox County High School sponsored by the Jr. Womaas Club of Appomattox. In charge of the parade this year, is the Oakvilb Ruritan Club with Mike Shafer, current president of the dub, srving as chairman. According to Shafer, there have been many entries received for the parade including floats, antique cars, equestrian entries, and many more attractions. Hootever, more bands are being solicited. Anyone interested in enter ing a unit for judging in the parade, may contact Mike . Shafer a t352-7816. There has been much recreation planned for the kiddies this year according to Marvin House, Jr,, represent ing the Woodmen of the World who is in charge of all recreational facilities. Plans indude a choo-choo train from the W.O.W. offering free rides to the kiddies, courtesy of local businesses. The Sesame Street characters, Woodsy the Owl, and Smokey the Bear will attend the parade and drulate on Main Street during the festival. Small kiddie rides will also be available. A special train display has been secured by the Bicentenn ial Commission in Appomattox from the Roanoke Chapter of National H istoric Railroad Society. Tommy Terry, from the Bicentennial Commissi, is in charge of the special train committee. Throe Cars indud- ing a coach, sleeper, and dining car will be available for touring and will offer railroad displays, movies and lecturers t o answer any questions regarding trains on railroad sodeties. document.text: The Fourth Annual Historic Appomattox Railroad Festival Board proudly announces the printing of a limited edition plate commenting the Fourth Annual Historic Appomattox Railroad Festival. Tim design for the plate fa the official seal of the Railroad Festival which was sketched by Clifford O. Rhedenizer, Jr . of Appomattox. Only 100 of these plates will be printed and therefore they are collectors items. They will be available during the festival week-end, October 16 and 17, or if you wish to purchase your plate early, you may contact Claudia Gordon, 852-7724 or Cajolyn Thompson, 352-7304.

document.text: The FINCASTLE RIFLES, a Civil War Unit reactivated for participation in reenactments of battles, will take part in the Third Annual Historic Appo mattox Railroad Festival on October 11 and 12. Officially, the FINCASTLE RIFLES are Company D, 11th Virginia Infantry Regiment, CSA. The Company will present many activities during the Festival as they portray  Day In The Life Of A Civil War Soldier. On Saturday mor ning, October 11th Company D will assemble for the parade at the Appomattox Primary School as the Regimental drummer beats the Long Roll, the assembly call for infantry during the War Between the States. The unit will then march through Appomattox, turn and stop at the corner of Lee and Atwood Streets, break ranks and set up a camp that will be typical of the way the soldiers of the Confederate Army set up a campsite. Among the activities that will be presented are cooking of typical foods the soldiers ate, demonstrations of the Manual of Arms according to the 1861

document.text: The Eighth Annual His toric Appomattox Railroad Festival will include a Super Hobo obstacle course as a new event this year. Gordon Ford, chairman of special contests says the race wHL be similar to the Race of the Superstars. Obstacles included will be a wall, tunnel, tires, hanging bars, sleds, water, and hurdles. Registration is open to anyone fourteen and over. There is no entry fee simply sign up before the race begins on Sunday, October 12, run the race, then post your time. Rules and prizes will be posted at the Festival Hobo site. Follow Railroad Willie to more Hobo fun sack race, three legged race, club 10 man team tug of war, and more. Contact Gordon Ford 352 5204 for more informa -lion or if you wish to , volunteer your services.

document.text: The Appomattox Junior Womans Club, lac. met on Tues., Oct. 28 in the Community Room of the Farmers National Bank, Tri angle Plaza Branch. Mrs. James A. Nolen, president of the club, presided at the meeting. The program was presented by the Home Life Department  and Mrs. W. Addison Elder, chairman, introduced the guest panel for the evening. Mr. Roland Murphy and Mrs. D. Barksdale informed club mem bers of area Juvenile problems j and projects. One of the specific topics discussed was child I abuse and club members questioned the panel about this problem. The program was followed by a business session and an evaluation of the clubs effectiveness in sponsoring the annual Historic. Appomattox Railroad Festival was the focal point of the discussion. A team of club members consisting of Mrs. John M. Fedison, Mrs. Charles Perkins, Mrs. Richard Robinson and Mrs. Robert Stewart was appointed by Mrs. Nolen to present ideas concern ing the festival to other organizations and agencies in the Appomattox community. Hostessesi for the October meeting were Mrs. John Canada. Mrs. W. Addison Elder and Mrs. Woody Jackson.

document.text: The Appomattox Junior Womans Club, Inc. formally opened its 1975-75 club year with a dinner meeting on Tuesday evening. Sept. 23, at Maudes R estaurant. Mrs. James A. Nolen, president, conducted the meeting. The club celebrated its 20 anniversary with many charter members of 1955 present. Some of those past members attend ing were Mrs. Kenneth Coleman, Mrs. Paul Doss, Mrs. Audrey Ferguson, Mrs. Sam Conner, Mrs. Billy Chenault, Mrs. Grover Beasley, Mrs. Fred Lawson, Mrs. Shearer Robertson, Mrs. A b n e r Scruggs and Mrs. Crawford Davidson. Mrs. Annie Mae Emerson, president of the Alice Kyle District was also in attendance and Mrs. Robert W. Carter, Sr., president of the AJWC during 1972-74, gave a recent account of the clubs accomplishments. At the meeting, the following new members were installed Miss Patricia Butler, Mrs. Walter Hancock, Jr., Mrs. Woody Jackson, Miss Evelyn Heising, Mrs. Thomas Lawson, Mrs. Ray Lewis, Mrs. Gilbert Lusk, Mrs. Ronald Steinkamp, and Mrs. Michael Torrence. Mrs. Robert Stewart gave a progress report on the 1975 Railroad Festival and the club voted to donate 25.00 to the Crippled Childrens Hospital in Richmond.   The next meeting of the dub will be on October 28,

document.text: The Appomattox Junior Wo mens Club held their October meeting at the Triangle Plaza Branch of Farmers National Bank Tuesday evening, Oct. 22nd. Special guests and speakers for the evening program were Mrs. Maureen Watkins, Junior Director of Alice Kyle District and Mrs. Anna Hooper, State Communications Vice-Chair man and District Recording Coordinator. Mrs. Watkins spoke to the club on chairmanship responsi bilities within the club. Mem bers of the club were compli mented on the organization and effectiveness of the various committees and departments already demonstrated by the success of the 2nd Annual Railroad Festival of the Junior Womens Club co-sponsored with the Town of Appomattox. Mrs. Watkins attended the festival as a guest of the club. document.text: The Appomattox Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy met on Thursday March 18th at 730 p.m. at Fanners National Bank, Tri angle Plaza Branch. There were, 12 members in attendance and one visitor. Pledges to the United States Flag and Salutes of the V irginia Flag and the Confederate Flag were led by the president, Mrs. Lena Eversole. The ritual was read by Mrs.?Harriet Cunning ham and the Confederate Prayer by Mrs. Thelma Martin. Mrs. Eversole asked mem bers to bring ideas to the next meeting that we may begin making plans for the Railroad Festival to be held October 16 and 17th. Mrs. Lucille Ferrell, Histor ian, gave an interesting talk on Confederate Congress during the years of the Civil War. On Tuesday April 6 at 200 p.m . the Kirkwood Otery U .D .C. Chapter, will hold their meeting .at. th National Park with a guest speaker. The Appomattox Chapter will join them and afterward all the group will meet in the home of Mrs. Rachel Lawson for a social hour. Members enjoyed delicious refreshments served by the hostesses, Mrs. John P. Baker, Mrs. Kitty Godsey, Mrs. Ina Harvey, Mrs. Marion Tweedy, and Mrs. Tilden Lee.
